editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

WHereas by divers late ExpreÅ¿Å¿es and Letters to the Citie of London, we found our Å¿elves aimed at by His Sacred MajeÅ¿tie, as men that have diÅ¿turbed the publike peace of the Citie; of which we are in our owne conÅ¿ciences altogether guiltleÅ¿Å¿e, having neither acted nor attempted any thing againÅ¿t the tranquillitie thereof; nor had any intentions, but what tended to the true Å¿ervice of his MajeÅ¿tie, the good of the Common-wealth, and the Å¿ecuritie of the Citie of London. And have furthermore never done or imagined ought, but what we had juÅ¿t authoritie from the High Court of Parliament, which wee were bound in conÅ¿cience and equitie to obey, being Å¿o publikely, and in the eyes of the whole Kingdome, as well of this Citie, whereof wee are members, charged with delinquencie: We eÅ¿teemed our Å¿elves bound, in vindication of our innocence, to Å¿et forth theÅ¿e our Å¿erious Declarations of our owne integrities, knowing well that Å¿uch charges in the too credulous people, who cenÅ¿ure mens actions by the event, rather than intention, might beget an opinion that we are really guiltie; when before God and our conÅ¿ciences wee doe beleeve, and dare affirme wee have neither practiÅ¿ed, or attempted ought, which was not warrantable by
the knowne Lawes and conÅ¿titutions of the Kingdome, and for the defence of Gods true Religion and worÅ¿hip; yet Å¿ome malignants as it Å¿hould appeare, have informed His Å¿acred MajeÅ¿ty, and others have inÅ¿tilled the Å¿ame poyÅ¿on to our fames and reputations into the eares of the people, eÅ¿pecially in the City of London, that we have bin, & are deÅ¿irous to advance innovations in the true Church of England, and bring in Å¿trange doctrines of BrowniÅ¿me, AnabaptiÅ¿me, and the like, things Å¿o far from our thoughts, much leÅ¿Å¿e meanings that we Å¿hould Å¿carcely know their names, were we not inÅ¿tructed in them by thoÅ¿e as purÅ¿ue calumnies, which would make us if not the Authors, at leaÅ¿t the promoters and defenders of them, when for our parts we have alwayes eÅ¿teemed the doctrine of the Church of England perfect and Orthodoxall, and Å¿o have ever demeaned our Å¿elves as true Å¿onnes of the Å¿aid Church, though perhaps Å¿ome innovations and inÅ¿olencies (which are not unknowne to the whole world, attempted, if not committed by the BiÅ¿hops and Prelates) upon the perÅ¿ons and eÅ¿tates of Å¿undry of Gods faithfull Å¿ervants, might make us deÅ¿ire an abatement of their pride, and a reformation of thoÅ¿e groÅ¿Å¿e abuÅ¿es which they Å¿ought by their unlimited power and authority to obtrude upon the Church; and therein Å¿urely we performed nothing but what was agreeable to the juÅ¿tice of Gods and the Kingdomes Lawes, and what equally deÅ¿ired by the whole body of the Kingdome now aÅ¿Å¿embled in this preÅ¿ent Parliament for the Å¿ame end; namely, to rectifie and reforme thoÅ¿e Å¿o long predominant errours in the Church, which had almoÅ¿t growne up againe to that aboliÅ¿hed doctrine of PapiÅ¿me in this Realme, and obÅ¿cured the verity of true Religion, by their Ceremonies and circumÅ¿tances, which were as vaine and uÅ¿eleÅ¿Å¿e as they were Å¿uperÅ¿titious and ridiculous, if not prophane and impious; yet for this our integrity, we know that divers have been apt to cenÅ¿ure us, and impute this our zeale in Gods cauÅ¿e, to a deÅ¿ire of Innovation; But Å¿urely our innocence acquits us of thoÅ¿e Å¿candals, and
they might as well blame Iehu for Å¿eeking to deÅ¿troy all thoÅ¿e in IÅ¿rael that had bowed to Baal, as us for our proÅ¿ecution by the Lawes of the Land, convicted PapiÅ¿ts and RecuÅ¿ants; and charged him therby, that he intended an innovation rather then a reformation in the Religion of the IÅ¿raelites. For any other of our attempts or practiÅ¿es with which we Å¿tand charged, as namely, or at leaÅ¿t by evident circumÅ¿tance, for advancing the affaires of the Common wealth, and being Å¿ubÅ¿ervient to the commands of the Honourable the High Court of Parliament, by putting their ordinances in practiÅ¿e for the levying of monies upon the inhabitants of the City of London, to help to defray the charge of the Army raiÅ¿ed for the defence of His MajeÅ¿ty and Parliament, certainly we had moÅ¿t convincing reaÅ¿ons to indeare it as much as lay in our powers: For firÅ¿t, we beheld the Kingdome torne and dilacerated into a thouÅ¿and diÅ¿tractions by the counÅ¿els of malignants, who meerly aimed at their owne wicked and Å¿iniÅ¿ter ends, and for that purpoÅ¿e, by their Å¿editious deviÅ¿es had Å¿eparated His MajeÅ¿ty from His High Court of Parliament, convocated by His Å¿acred authority, to treat of the doubtfull and difficult affaires of the Kingdome, and to Å¿et at right the oppreÅ¿Å¿ive abuÅ¿es thereof, the Å¿aid malignants Å¿eeking utterly to deÅ¿troy the eÅ¿Å¿ence of Parliaments, wherein the Å¿afety of the Subject principally conÅ¿iÅ¿ts, as is not unknowne to all well affected perÅ¿ons. We beheld likewiÅ¿e by the perverÅ¿e counÅ¿ell of the Å¿aid malignants, an Army raiÅ¿ed by His MajeÅ¿ties command, for what end we could not conjecture, unleÅ¿Å¿e for the deÅ¿truction of the Kingdome, the Å¿ubduing the people, and Å¿ubverting the fundamentall Lawes of the Land, which Army, how deÅ¿tructive it hath been to the good Å¿ubjects of the Realme, the inhumane plundrings of the Cavaliers, their taking away peoples eÅ¿tates, firing their houÅ¿es, and murdering their perÅ¿ons, hath given to the whole world a Å¿ufficient teÅ¿timony, and after their bloudy perambulation through moÅ¿t of the Counties of the Kingdome, and their commitment of robberies and maÅ¿Å¿acres. We beheld
them drawing their forces this way towards this noble City of London, which was the marke their avarice Å¿hot at, the end which they in their ravenous minds had intended by all probabilities to arrive, the abundant wealth and infinite riches of this great and populous City, being that Å¿upply which they expected Å¿hould build up the ruines of their decayed fortunes, and be an ample Å¿alary for their deÅ¿perate deÅ¿ignes, which had almoÅ¿t devoured the wealth of the whole Kingdome, and only thirÅ¿ted for the Å¿poyles of us and our families.

BeÅ¿ides, in the Å¿aid army wee were as certaine there were gathered together as well Commanders as Soulders, divers notorious PopiÅ¿h RecuÅ¿ants, who by the Lawes of the land ought not onely to beare armes, but likewiÅ¿e to be diÅ¿inabled from bearing armes, by taking away all their military furniture, and proviÅ¿ion of warre: the whole Kingdome at leaÅ¿t the well-affected perÅ¿ons thereof, evidently knowing that the Å¿word being once put into the hands of PapiÅ¿ts, they would uÅ¿e it without all mercy againÅ¿t the breaÅ¿ts of all true ProteÅ¿tants, and Å¿uch as were zealous in the worÅ¿hip of the Almighty; yet this Army wee Å¿aw drawne downe (at leaÅ¿t the better part thereof,) even to our very dores, within five miles of our habitations, threatening the City of London, and the Parliament there Å¿itting with unavoyded ruine, if they had not beene prevented, and the utter extirpation, as it was probable enough, of Gods true Religion; Å¿urrounded therefore with Å¿o many dangers and imminent perills which hung like Å¿o many teeming clouds over our heads, menacing deÅ¿truction to our wives, houÅ¿es and families; nay, deÅ¿olation to the whole Citie, let all the world be but indifferent judges, whether we, who were interreÅ¿Å¿ed with the chiefe charge and care of the City, had not reaÅ¿on to looke about us, and provide for the Å¿afety of the City, one of us having the principall governement thereof, and the reÅ¿t of us being able and Å¿ufficient Members of the Å¿aid City, whether
we had not cauÅ¿e not onely to put the Order of the high Court of Parliament in practice with diligence, for the raiÅ¿ing men and moneys for the defence of our Å¿elves and the City, but alÅ¿o to render them condigne and humble thankes for their care and proviÅ¿ion for our Å¿ecurities, and whether it was not requiÅ¿ite that the City of London, being the capitall place of the Kingdome, and the chiefeÅ¿t Magazine it hath both for wealth and armes, Å¿hould advance the greateÅ¿t Å¿ummes of moneys toward the Å¿upportment of theÅ¿e neceÅ¿Å¿ities, defenÅ¿ive warres undertaken by the command and order of Parliament for the Å¿afegard of the Å¿ubjects liberties, and the Å¿ecurity of the true ProteÅ¿tant Religion. Certainly had the Citizens contributed in Å¿tead of the twentieth part the halfe of their EÅ¿tates to an uÅ¿e Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary and pious, they had but made a juÅ¿t domonÅ¿tration of their loves to the Common-wealth, and their cares to their Å¿elves and families, it being farre more requiÅ¿ite for them to part with the twentieth part of their EÅ¿tates, Å¿o to Å¿ecure the reÅ¿t, then by the detention of that, not onely to hazard their whole lively hoods and fortunes, but their lives and liberties to the deÅ¿perate fury of thoÅ¿e Malignants and Cavaliers, who thinke of no other law, nor acknowledge no other conÅ¿cience but their inordinate luÅ¿ts. And Å¿o confident are we of our integrities, having done nothing but what hath beene authoriÅ¿ed us by Order from the high Court of Parliament; that wee both hope and believe when his Å¿acred MajeÅ¿ty, abandoning the counÅ¿ell of thoÅ¿e Malignants, who have incenÅ¿ed his goodneÅ¿Å¿e as well againÅ¿t his high Court of Parliament, as againÅ¿t us, Å¿hall really and rightly conÅ¿ider our actions and intentions, his Å¿acred wiÅ¿dome will not onely acquit our innocences of any diÅ¿-Å¿ervice to himÅ¿elfe, the tranquillity of the Kingdome, or welfare of the City of London, by our forwardneÅ¿Å¿e in Å¿etting forth the Order of the high Court of Parliament, and levying of moneys for the Å¿upport and
maintenance of theÅ¿e warres againÅ¿t the Cavaliers, but will thanke us for our diligence, which hath beene a principall meanes to preÅ¿erve the City of London from devaÅ¿tation and ruine, and defended Gods true Religion from the machinations of PopiÅ¿h RecuÅ¿ants; and for the Citizens of London, who may by the violence of the Å¿aid aÅ¿perÅ¿ions be drawne to believe the Å¿aid opinions, wee all hope they will by this our Vindication of our innocence, be perÅ¿waded to believe our integrities, which have alwayes tended to the Å¿ervice of his MajeÅ¿tie and the advancement of the Common-wealth, the defence of the ProteÅ¿tant Religion, and the demonÅ¿tration of our obedience to the honourable the high Court of Parliament.
